elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig1">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Coordination environment of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Thermal ellipsoids are shown at 50% probability with partial atom numbering scheme. Hydrogen atoms are represented as sticks. The coordination environment of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is very similar.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  Coordination environment of 1. Thermal ellipsoids are shown at 50% probability with partial atom numbering scheme. Hydrogen atoms are represented as sticks. The coordination environment of 2 is very similar.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig2">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">A [Co(glu)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> chain in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, with semi-ligating interactions shown as dashed lines. The semi-chelating oxygen atom is covalently bound at the apical site of the square pyramidal coordination environment.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  A [Co(glu)] n  chain in 1, with semi-ligating interactions shown as dashed lines. The semi-chelating oxygen atom is covalently bound at the apical site of the square pyramidal coordination environment.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig3">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">A single [Co(glu)(dpa)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> rectangular grid layer in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, viewed down the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> crystal direction.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr3"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  A single [Co(glu)(dpa)] n  rectangular grid layer in 1, viewed down the a crystal direction.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig4">
<ce:label>Fig. 4</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Schematic perspective of the unprecedented (3,5)-connected supramolecular binodal topology in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr4"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 4  Schematic perspective of the unprecedented (3,5)-connected supramolecular binodal topology in 1.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig5">
<ce:label>Fig. 5</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">(a, b) Coordination environments around Cu1 and Cu2 in the low temperature polymorph of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. (c) The unique coordination environment in the high temperature polymorph of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, showing the two positions of the disordered glutarate ligand. Thermal ellipsoids are shown at 50% probability.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr5"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 5  (a, b) Coordination environments around Cu1 and Cu2 in the low temperature polymorph of 3. (c) The unique coordination environment in the high temperature polymorph of 3, showing the two positions of the disordered glutarate ligand. Thermal ellipsoids are shown at 50% probability.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig6">
<ce:label>Fig. 6</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">(a) [Cu(glu)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> chain-A</ce:italic> motif in the low temperature polymorph of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. (b) [Cu(glu)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> chain-B</ce:italic> motif in the low temperature polymorph of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. (c) Unique [Cu(glu)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> chain motif in the low temperature polymorph of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. Semi-ligating interactions are shown as dashed lines.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr6"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 6  (a) [Cu(glu)] n chain-A motif in the low temperature polymorph of 3. (b) [Cu(glu)] n chain-B motif in the low temperature polymorph of 3. (c) Unique [Cu(glu)] n  chain motif in the low temperature polymorph of 3. Semi-ligating interactions are shown as dashed lines.

elements.content:

</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr7"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Hydrothermal reaction of divalent metal chlorides with glutaric acid and 4,4′-dipyridylamine (dpa) has afforded an isostructural family of coordination polymers with formulation [M(glu)(dpa)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (M=Co (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), Ni (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), Cu (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>); glu=glutarate). Square pyramidal coordination is seen in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, with semi-ligation of a sixth donor to produce a “5+1” extended coordination sphere. Neighboring metal atoms are linked into 1D [M(glu)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> neutral chains through chelating/monodentate bridging glutarate moieties with a <ce:italic>syn</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>anti</ce:italic> binding mode, and semi-chelation of the pendant carboxylate oxygen. These chains further connect into 2D layers through dipodal dpa ligands. Neighboring layers stack into the pseudo 3D crystal structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> through supramolecular hydrogen bonding between dpa amine units and the semi-chelated glutarate oxygen atoms. The variable temperature magnetic behavior of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> was explored and modeled as infinite 1D Heisenberg chains. Notably, complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> undergoes a thermally induced single crystal-to-single crystal transformation between centric and acentric space groups, with a conformationally disordered unilayer structure at 293<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>K and an ordered bilayer structure at 173<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>K. All materials were further characterized via infrared spectroscopy and elemental and thermogravimetric analyses.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Hydrothermal reaction of divalent metal chlorides with glutaric acid and 4,4'-dipyridylamine (dpa) has afforded an isostructural family of coordination polymers with formulation [M(glu)(dpa)] n  (M=Co (1), Ni (2), Cu (3); glu=glutarate). Square pyramidal coordination is seen in 1-3, with semi-ligation of a sixth donor to produce a "5+1" extended coordination sphere. Neighboring metal atoms are linked into 1D [M(glu)] n  neutral chains through chelating/monodentate bridging glutarate moieties with a syn-anti binding mode, and semi-chelation of the pendant carboxylate oxygen. These chains further connect into 2D layers through dipodal dpa ligands. Neighboring layers stack into the pseudo 3D crystal structure of 1-3 through supramolecular hydrogen bonding between dpa amine units and the semi-chelated glutarate oxygen atoms. The variable temperature magnetic behavior of 1-3 was explored and modeled as infinite 1D Heisenberg chains. Notably, complex 3 undergoes a thermally induced single crystal-to-single crystal transformation between centric and acentric space groups, with a conformationally disordered unilayer structure at 293K and an ordered bilayer structure at 173K. All materials were further characterized via infrared spectroscopy and elemental and thermogravimetric analyses.

</ce:italic> (M=Co (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), Ni (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), Cu (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>); glu=glutarate, dpa=4,4'-dipyridylamine) exhibit 2D layer structures based on 1D [M(glu)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> chains linked through dpa tethers. Antiferromagnetic coupling is observed for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, while ferromagnetism is predominant in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> undergoes a thermally induced single crystal-to-single crystal transformation from an acentric to a centrosymmetric space group.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

The coordination polymers [M(glu)(dpa)] n  (M=Co (1), Ni (2), Cu (3); glu=glutarate, dpa=4,4'-dipyridylamine) exhibit 2D layer structures based on 1D [M(glu)] n  chains linked through dpa tethers. Antiferromagnetic coupling is observed for 2 and 3, while ferromagnetism is predominant in 1. Compound 3 undergoes a thermally induced single crystal-to-single crystal transformation from an acentric to a centrosymmetric space group.

<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Over the past decade intense investigation has focused on dicarboxylate metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) due to their capabilities in gas storage , shape-selective separations , ion-exchange , catalysis , non-linear optics , luminescence , and magnetism . In these phases dianionic dicarboxylates act as tethering ligands to connect neighboring metal ions into a diverse range of structural motifs, hinged on the disposition of donor atoms and the ability of these ligands to adopt a wide variety of binding modes and to provide loci for structure-directing supramolecular hydrogen bonding interactions. They also allow the charge balance necessary to permit self-assembly of neutral MOFs without the incorporation of smaller anions that could inhibit formation of void spaces. The level of structural complexity in dicarboxylate MOFs can be enhanced through the introduction of neutral nitrogen-based tethering ligands such as 4,4′-bipyridine (4,4′-bpy), which can connect metal cations through its distal pyridyl nitrogen donor atoms into structurally intriguing solids with interesting physicochemical properties . For example, the 2D layered phase [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O(isophthalate)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(4,4′-bpy)] has potential use as a blue luminescent material , and the interpenetrated 3D material [Zn(terephthalate)(4,4′-bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>] can chromatographically separate branched and linear hydrocarbons .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Over the past decade intense investigation has focused on dicarboxylate metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) due to their capabilities in gas storage , shape-selective separations , ion-exchange , catalysis , non-linear optics , luminescence , and magnetism . In these phases dianionic dicarboxylates act as tethering ligands to connect neighboring metal ions into a diverse range of structural motifs, hinged on the disposition of donor atoms and the ability of these ligands to adopt a wide variety of binding modes and to provide loci for structure-directing supramolecular hydrogen bonding interactions. They also allow the charge balance necessary to permit self-assembly of neutral MOFs without the incorporation of smaller anions that could inhibit formation of void spaces. The level of structural complexity in dicarboxylate MOFs can be enhanced through the introduction of neutral nitrogen-based tethering ligands such as 4,4'-bipyridine (4,4'-bpy), which can connect metal cations through its distal pyridyl nitrogen donor atoms into structurally intriguing solids with interesting physicochemical properties . For example, the 2D layered phase [Zn4O(isophthalate)3(4,4'-bpy)] has potential use as a blue luminescent material , and the interpenetrated 3D material [Zn(terephthalate)(4,4'-bpy)0.5] can chromatographically separate branched and linear hydrocarbons .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Compared with benzenedicarboxylate MOFs, organodiimine-scaffolded coordination polymers based on longer aliphatic α,ω-dicarboxylates have received less attention . While the structural rigidity of benzenedicarboxylate subunits is advantageous for the construction of porous materials, flexible aliphatic dicarboxylates can provoke novel structural motifs due to their ability to access numerous energetically similar conformations. For instance, a few divalent metal adipate (adp) coordination polymers incorporating 4,4′-bpy or bpe have been reported, in all cases manifesting interpenetrated 3D networks with the well-known α-Po topology .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compared with benzenedicarboxylate MOFs, organodiimine-scaffolded coordination polymers based on longer aliphatic α,ω-dicarboxylates have received less attention . While the structural rigidity of benzenedicarboxylate subunits is advantageous for the construction of porous materials, flexible aliphatic dicarboxylates can provoke novel structural motifs due to their ability to access numerous energetically similar conformations. For instance, a few divalent metal adipate (adp) coordination polymers incorporating 4,4'-bpy or bpe have been reported, in all cases manifesting interpenetrated 3D networks with the well-known α-Po topology .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">For some time we have been interested in the synthesis and characterization of coordination polymers containing the organodiimine 4,4′-dipyridylamine (dpa). Unlike 4,4′-bpy, dpa possesses a kinked disposition of its terminal nitrogen donor atoms as well as a hydrogen bonding locus at its center, allowing it to promote the formation of novel structural patterns via supramolecular as well as covalent interactions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: For some time we have been interested in the synthesis and characterization of coordination polymers containing the organodiimine 4,4'-dipyridylamine (dpa). Unlike 4,4'-bpy, dpa possesses a kinked disposition of its terminal nitrogen donor atoms as well as a hydrogen bonding locus at its center, allowing it to promote the formation of novel structural patterns via supramolecular as well as covalent interactions.

</ce:italic>, a material exhibiting a rather common two-fold interpenetrated primitive cubic 6-connected lattice. However, use of a divalent nickel precursor resulted in the crystallization of [Ni(adipate)(dpa)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:italic>

</ce:italic>, which is the first example of a triply interpenetrated PtS framework (binodal 4<ce:sup loc="pre">2</ce:sup>8<ce:sup loc="pre">4</ce:sup> topology). Herein we report the first dpa-containing glutarate (glu, 1,5-pentanedicarboxylate,

<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (M=Co, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; M=Ni, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>; M=Cu, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>). Thermal and magnetic properties of these materials are also discussed, along with a curious thermally-induced ordered to disordered single crystal-to-single crystal (SCSC) transition in the case of compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Combination of dpa and α,ω-dicarboxylic acids with appropriate metal precursors under hydrothermal conditions has resulted in the construction of extended solids with interesting and diverse structural motifs . For instance, [Co(succinate)(dpa)2] n  displays homochiral 1D helices linked together via dpa-mediated hydrogen bonding. {[Cu(succinate)(dpa)]⋅0.5H2O} n  adopts a rarely seen two-fold interpenetrated CdSO4 lattice (658 topology), while {[Ni(dpa)2(succinate)0.5]Cl} n  manifested a unique uniform 5-connected self-penetrated 610 topology (rld-z) network . The longer chain α,ω-dicarboxylate adipate allowed formation of [Co(adipate)(dpa)] n , a material exhibiting a rather common two-fold interpenetrated primitive cubic 6-connected lattice. However, use of a divalent nickel precursor resulted in the crystallization of [Ni(adipate)(dpa)(H2O)] n , which is the first example of a triply interpenetrated PtS framework (binodal 4284 topology). Herein we report the first dpa-containing glutarate (glu, 1,5-pentanedicarboxylate,  ) coordination polymers with the hydrothermal synthesis and structural characterization of three related complexes, [M(glu)(dpa)] n  (M=Co, 1; M=Ni, 2; M=Cu, 3). Thermal and magnetic properties of these materials are also discussed, along with a curious thermally-induced ordered to disordered single crystal-to-single crystal (SCSC) transition in the case of compound 3.

<ce:section-title>Experimental section</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>General considerations</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">CoCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>

<ce:bold>·</ce:bold>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (Fisher), and glutaric acid (Aldrich) were obtained commercially. 4,4′-dipyridylamine (dpa) was prepared via a published procedure . Water was deionized above 3<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>MΩ in-house. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed on TA Instruments TGA 2050 thermogravimetric analyzer with a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>°C/min up to 900<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>°C under flowing N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. Elemental Analysis was carried out using a Perkin–Elmer 2400 Series II CHNS/O Analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Mattson Galaxy FTIR Series 3000 using KBr pellets. Powder X-ray diffraction on ground samples of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> for phase purity verification were obtained via <ce:italic>Θ–</ce:italic>2<ce:italic>Θ</ce:italic> scans performed on a Rigaku Rotaflex instrument. Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility data (2–300<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>K) was collected on a Quantum Design MPMS SQUID magnetometer at an applied field of 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>T. After each temperature change the sample was kept at the new temperature for 5<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>min before magnetization measurement to ensure thermal equilibrium. The susceptibility data was corrected for diamagnetism using Pascal's constants . Differential scanning calorimetry on a sample of crystalline <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> was carried out using a TA Instruments DSC 2010 instrument.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental section

General considerations

CoCl2 ⋅6H2O, NiCl2 ⋅6H2O, CuCl2 ⋅2H2O (Fisher), and glutaric acid (Aldrich) were obtained commercially. 4,4'-dipyridylamine (dpa) was prepared via a published procedure . Water was deionized above 3MΩ in-house. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed on TA Instruments TGA 2050 thermogravimetric analyzer with a heating rate of 10°C/min up to 900°C under flowing N2. Elemental Analysis was carried out using a Perkin-Elmer 2400 Series II CHNS/O Analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Mattson Galaxy FTIR Series 3000 using KBr pellets. Powder X-ray diffraction on ground samples of 1-3 for phase purity verification were obtained via Θ-2Θ scans performed on a Rigaku Rotaflex instrument. Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility data (2-300K) was collected on a Quantum Design MPMS SQUID magnetometer at an applied field of 0.1T. After each temperature change the sample was kept at the new temperature for 5min before magnetization measurement to ensure thermal equilibrium. The susceptibility data was corrected for diamagnetism using Pascal's constants . Differential scanning calorimetry on a sample of crystalline 3 was carried out using a TA Instruments DSC 2010 instrument.

<ce:section-title>Preparation of [Co(glu)(dpa)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">CoCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>·</ce:bold>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (88<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.37<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>mmol), dpa (127<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.73<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>mmol), and glutaric acid (49<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.37<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>mmol) were placed into 10<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>mL distilled H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in a 23<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon-lined Parr acid digestion bomb. The bomb was sealed and heated at 120<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>°C for 48<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>h, whereupon it was cooled slowly to 25<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>°C. Large single crystalline blocks of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (110<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>mg, 82% yield based on Co) were isolated after washing with distilled water, ethanol, and acetone and drying in air. Preparation of [Co(glu)(dpa)]n (1)

CoCl2 ⋅6H2O (88mg, 0.37mmol), dpa (127mg, 0.73mmol), and glutaric acid (49mg, 0.37mmol) were placed into 10mL distilled H2O in a 23mL Teflon-lined Parr acid digestion bomb. The bomb was sealed and heated at 120°C for 48h, whereupon it was cooled slowly to 25°C. Large single crystalline blocks of 1 (110mg, 82% yield based on Co) were isolated after washing with distilled water, ethanol, and acetone and drying in air. Crystals of 1 display pleochroism, appearing brown, orange, or violet depending on their orientation with respect to a bright light source. Anal. Calc. for C15H15CoN3O4 1: C, 50.01; H, 4.20; N, 11.67%. Found: C, 49.50; H, 3.93; N, 11.43%. <ce:section-title>X-ray crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">A brown block of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (with dimensions 0.78<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>mm×0.56<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>mm×0.48<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>mm), a green block of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (0.42<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>mm×0.20<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>mm×0.18<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>mm), and a blue block of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (0.24<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>mm×0.10<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>mm×0.10<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>mm) were subjected to single crystal X-ray diffraction using a Bruker-AXS SMART 1k CCD instrument at 173<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>K. The X-ray diffraction experiment for the same single crystal of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> was repeated at 293<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>K. Reflection data was acquired using graphite-monochromated Mo<ce:italic>K</ce:italic>α radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>=0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å). The data was integrated via SAINT . Lorentz and polarization effect and empirical absorption corrections were applied with SADABS . The structures were solved using direct methods and refined on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> using SHELXTL . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms bound to carbon atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined isotropically with a riding model. The hydrogen atoms bound to the central nitrogen of the dpa moieties in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were found via Fourier difference maps, then restrained at fixed positions and refined isotropically. Attempts to refine the crystal structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> using the low temperature reflection data in the higher symmetry centrosymmetric space group <ce:italic>Pbcm</ce:italic> with a disordered glutarate conformation model resulted in unacceptably high <ce:italic>wR<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> values (∼0.52), with 355 systematic absence violations. Acceptable solution was possible only in <ce:italic>Pca</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> with racemic twinning taken into account. Conversely, the crystal structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> could not be acceptably solved in an acentric orthorhombic space group using the high temperature reflection data. Relevant crystallographic data for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and <ce:bold>3 (</ce:bold>at both 173 and 293<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>K) are listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

A brown block of 1 (with dimensions 0.78mm×0.56mm×0.48mm), a green block of 2 (0.42mm×0.20mm×0.18mm), and a blue block of 3 (0.24mm×0.10mm×0.10mm) were subjected to single crystal X-ray diffraction using a Bruker-AXS SMART 1k CCD instrument at 173K. The X-ray diffraction experiment for the same single crystal of 3 was repeated at 293K. Reflection data was acquired using graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ=0.71073Å). The data was integrated via SAINT . Lorentz and polarization effect and empirical absorption corrections were applied with SADABS . The structures were solved using direct methods and refined on F 2 using SHELXTL . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms bound to carbon atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined isotropically with a riding model. The hydrogen atoms bound to the central nitrogen of the dpa moieties in 1-3 were found via Fourier difference maps, then restrained at fixed positions and refined isotropically. Attempts to refine the crystal structure of 3 using the low temperature reflection data in the higher symmetry centrosymmetric space group Pbcm with a disordered glutarate conformation model resulted in unacceptably high wR2  values (~0.52), with 355 systematic absence violations. Acceptable solution was possible only in Pca21 with racemic twinning taken into account. Conversely, the crystal structure of 3 could not be acceptably solved in an acentric orthorhombic space group using the high temperature reflection data. Relevant crystallographic data for 1, 2, and 3 (at both 173 and 293K) are listed in  .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis and spectral characterization</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The coordination polymers <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were prepared as single phase crystalline products under hydrothermal conditions via combination of the appropriate metal chloride, 4,4′-dipyridylamine, and glutaric acid. The infrared spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were fully consistent with their formulations. Features corresponding to pyridyl ring puckering mechanisms were evident in the region between 800 and 600<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. Sharp, medium intensity bands in the range of ∼1600–∼1200<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> were ascribed to stretching modes of the pyridyl rings of the dpa moieties . Asymmetric and symmetric C–O stretching modes of the glutarate carboxylate moieties were evidenced by very strong, slightly broadened bands at ∼1580 and ∼1350<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The multiplicity of peaks in this region corroborates the presence of different binding modes present at each glutarate carboxylate terminus. Bands in the region of ∼3400<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> in all cases represent N–H stretching modes within the dpa ligands; their broadness is indicative of hydrogen bonding to carboxylate oxygen atoms (vide infra).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis and spectral characterization

The coordination polymers 1-3 were prepared as single phase crystalline products under hydrothermal conditions via combination of the appropriate metal chloride, 4,4'-dipyridylamine, and glutaric acid. The infrared spectra of 1-3 were fully consistent with their formulations. Features corresponding to pyridyl ring puckering mechanisms were evident in the region between 800 and 600cm-1. Sharp, medium intensity bands in the range of ~1600-~1200cm-1 were ascribed to stretching modes of the pyridyl rings of the dpa moieties . Asymmetric and symmetric C-O stretching modes of the glutarate carboxylate moieties were evidenced by very strong, slightly broadened bands at ~1580 and ~1350cm-1. The multiplicity of peaks in this region corroborates the presence of different binding modes present at each glutarate carboxylate terminus. Bands in the region of ~3400cm-1 in all cases represent N-H stretching modes within the dpa ligands; their broadness is indicative of hydrogen bonding to carboxylate oxygen atoms (vide infra).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Structural description of [M(glu)(dpa)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (M=Co, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; M=Ni, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">As revealed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are isomorphous and crystallize in the centrosymmetric orthorhombic space group <ce:italic>Pbcn</ce:italic> with an asymmetric unit consisting of one divalent metal ion, one glu dianion and one ligated dpa molecule (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>, shown for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>). The metal atoms display a distorted square pyramidal [MN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>] coordination geometry (<ce:italic>τ</ce:italic>=0.223 for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 0.224 for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)  with <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> nitrogen donors from two different dpa ligands anchoring the basal plane. A glu dianion in a 1,5-chelating binding mode fulfills the apical coordination site and one position in the basal plane. The glu ligands in these complexes adopt <ce:italic>gauche</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>gauche</ce:italic> conformations with four C-atom torsion angles of 62.6° and 65.9° for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 62.2° and 65.4° for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The fourth and final basal plane coordination site in each case is occupied by an oxygen atom from a second glu ligand. Bond lengths and angles () are consistent with divalent cobalt and nickel in a distorted square pyramidal coordination environment, with subtle differences consistent with well-established ionic radius trends .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structural description of [M(glu)(dpa)] n  (M=Co, 1; M=Ni, 2)

As revealed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, compounds 1 and 2 are isomorphous and crystallize in the centrosymmetric orthorhombic space group Pbcn with an asymmetric unit consisting of one divalent metal ion, one glu dianion and one ligated dpa molecule ( , shown for 1). The metal atoms display a distorted square pyramidal [MN2O3] coordination geometry (τ=0.223 for 1, 0.224 for 2)  with trans nitrogen donors from two different dpa ligands anchoring the basal plane. A glu dianion in a 1,5-chelating binding mode fulfills the apical coordination site and one position in the basal plane. The glu ligands in these complexes adopt gauche-gauche conformations with four C-atom torsion angles of 62.6° and 65.9° for 1 and 62.2° and 65.4° for 2. The fourth and final basal plane coordination site in each case is occupied by an oxygen atom from a second glu ligand. Bond lengths and angles () are consistent with divalent cobalt and nickel in a distorted square pyramidal coordination environment, with subtle differences consistent with well-established ionic radius trends .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Adjacent metal ions are conjoined into zigzag 1D [M(glu)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> chains parallel to the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> crystal direction (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>) through bridging glu carboxylate termini in a <ce:italic>syn</ce:italic>-<ce:italic>anti</ce:italic> binding mode, in which the basal plane of one square pyramidal coordination sphere is linked to the apical position of another. The M<ce:bold>···</ce:bold>M distances along the chain motifs in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> measure 4.294 and 4.264<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. Covalent connectivity within the [M(glu)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> chains is supplemented by semi-ligation  on the part of one of the oxygen donor atoms involved in the 1,5-chelating binding mode of the glu ligands. This oxygen donor atom is bound at the apical coordination site of one metal ion, and donates electron density towards the vacant coordination site of another metal ion. Thus, a 1D repeating [M<ce:bold>···</ce:bold>O–M<ce:bold>···</ce:bold>O–]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> chain within the larger [M(glu)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> chain unit can be invoked. The semi-ligating M<ce:bold>···</ce:bold>O distances in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are 2.432 and 2.417<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively, causing respective M<ce:bold>···</ce:bold>O–M angles of 144.4° and 145.2°.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Adjacent metal ions are conjoined into zigzag 1D [M(glu)] n  chains parallel to the b crystal direction ( ) through bridging glu carboxylate termini in a syn-anti binding mode, in which the basal plane of one square pyramidal coordination sphere is linked to the apical position of another. The M⋅⋅⋅M distances along the chain motifs in 1 and 2 measure 4.294 and 4.264Å, respectively. Covalent connectivity within the [M(glu)] n  chains is supplemented by semi-ligation  on the part of one of the oxygen donor atoms involved in the 1,5-chelating binding mode of the glu ligands. This oxygen donor atom is bound at the apical coordination site of one metal ion, and donates electron density towards the vacant coordination site of another metal ion. Thus, a 1D repeating [M⋅⋅⋅O-M⋅⋅⋅O-] n  chain within the larger [M(glu)] n  chain unit can be invoked. The semi-ligating M⋅⋅⋅O distances in 1 and 2 are 2.432 and 2.417Å, respectively, causing respective M⋅⋅⋅O-M angles of 144.4° and 145.2°.

The M<ce:bold>···</ce:bold>M contact distances through the bridging dpa ligands are 11.806 (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and 11.701<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), with an inter-ring torsion within the dpa ligands of 28.7° (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and 28.1° (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>). The [M(glu)(dpa)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> single layers in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> contrast with those in the similar manganese complex [Mn(glu)(4,4′-bpy)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>
. In this latter material, [Mn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(glu)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> double chains, which lack any sort of M–O<ce:bold>···</ce:bold>M interaction, are linked into a thick 2D slab by the dipyridyl tethers.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Juxtaposed [M(glu)] n  chains in 1 and 2 are linked into (4,4) rectangular grid ruffled 2D [M(glu)(dpa)] n  layer parallels to the bc crystal plane by exobidentate dpa ligands ( ). The M⋅⋅⋅M contact distances through the bridging dpa ligands are 11.806 (1) and 11.701Å (2), with an inter-ring torsion within the dpa ligands of 28.7° (1) and 28.1° (2). The [M(glu)(dpa)] n  single layers in 1 and 2 contrast with those in the similar manganese complex [Mn(glu)(4,4'-bpy)] n  . In this latter material, [Mn2(glu)2] n  double chains, which lack any sort of M-O⋅⋅⋅M interaction, are linked into a thick 2D slab by the dipyridyl tethers.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Neighboring [M(glu)(dpa)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> layers are organized into <ce:italic>pseudo</ce:italic> three-dimensional structures by hydrogen bonding donation between the dpa central amine units projecting above and below each layer, and semi-chelating carboxylate oxygen atoms belonging to glu ligands in two other layers (Fig. S1). To facilitate this supramolecular interaction, the individual layers are arranged in an offset <ce:italic>ABA</ce:italic> stacking pattern. Geometrical parameters for the interlayer hydrogen bonding patterns in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl2"></ce:float-anchor>. Considering the nitrogen atoms at the dpa ligands’ central nitrogen atoms as three-connected nodes, and the metal atoms as five-connected nodes, the overall supramolecular structures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be visualized as a (3,5)-connected 3D network with an unprecedented binodal (4.6<ce:sup loc="pre">2</ce:sup>)(4.6<ce:sup loc="pre">5</ce:sup>.8<ce:sup loc="pre">4</ce:sup>) topology (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>), as analyzed via TOPOS software .</ce:para>

To facilitate this supramolecular interaction, the individual layers are arranged in an offset ABA stacking pattern. Geometrical parameters for the interlayer hydrogen bonding patterns in 1 and 2 are listed in  . elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Structural description and single crystal-to-single crystal transformation of [Cu(glu)(dpa)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">As done for crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, an X-ray diffraction experiment was performed at 173<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>K on a single crystal of compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. Dissimilar to <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the complex crystallized in the acentric orthorhombic space group <ce:italic>Pca</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>, with an asymmetric unit consisting of two divalent copper atoms, two glutarate dianions, and two dpa moieties (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>a and b). Both Cu1 and Cu2 possess distorted square pyramidal [MN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>] coordination geometry (<ce:italic>τ</ce:italic>=0.273 and 0.261, respectively) with very similar arrangements and binding modes of glu and dpa ligands to those seen in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. Nevertheless there are subtle variations in bond lengths and angles about the copper atoms (). Here, the glu dianion bound to Cu1 adopts a <ce:italic>gauche–anti</ce:italic> conformation (torsion angles=66.1/153.3°), while that bound to Cu2 rests in a <ce:italic>gauche</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>gauche</ce:italic> conformation (torsion angles=66.3/62.4°). No crystallographic disorder is evident in the glu ligands in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> at 173<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>K; attempts to model the structure in a higher symmetry centrosymmetric space group with one copper atom, one dpa ligand, and one disordered glu ligand failed.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structural description and single crystal-to-single crystal transformation of [Cu(glu)(dpa)] n  (3)

As done for crystals of 1 and 2, an X-ray diffraction experiment was performed at 173K on a single crystal of compound 3. Dissimilar to 1 and 2, the complex crystallized in the acentric orthorhombic space group Pca21, with an asymmetric unit consisting of two divalent copper atoms, two glutarate dianions, and two dpa moieties ( a and b). Both Cu1 and Cu2 possess distorted square pyramidal [MN2O3] coordination geometry (τ=0.273 and 0.261, respectively) with very similar arrangements and binding modes of glu and dpa ligands to those seen in 1 and 2. Nevertheless there are subtle variations in bond lengths and angles about the copper atoms (). Here, the glu dianion bound to Cu1 adopts a gauche-anti conformation (torsion angles=66.1/153.3°), while that bound to Cu2 rests in a gauche-gauche conformation (torsion angles=66.3/62.4°). No crystallographic disorder is evident in the glu ligands in 3 at 173K; attempts to model the structure in a higher symmetry centrosymmetric space group with one copper atom, one dpa ligand, and one disordered glu ligand failed.

<ce:float-anchor refid="fig6"></ce:float-anchor>a) with a Cu<ce:bold>···</ce:bold>Cu distance of 4.694<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å. Similarly, neighboring Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atoms are conjoined via <ce:italic>gauche–gauche</ce:italic> conformation glu ligands to form crystallographically distinct [Cu(glu)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>

The varying glu conformations instill different twists of neighboring copper square pyramidal coordination spheres (29° in <ce:italic>chain</ce:italic>-<ce:italic>A</ce:italic>, 43<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>° in <ce:italic>chain</ce:italic>-<ce:italic>B</ce:italic>). Cu<ce:bold>···</ce:bold>O semi-ligation within both <ce:italic>chain-A</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>chain-B</ce:italic> provides [Cu<ce:bold>···</ce:bold>O–Cu<ce:bold>···</ce:bold>O–]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> chain patterns, with Cu<ce:bold>···</ce:bold>O distances of 2.778 and 2.600<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å within <ce:italic>chain-A</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>chain-B</ce:italic>, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Adjacent Cu1 atoms are linked through the gauch-anti conformation glu ligands to form [Cu(glu)] n  1D chains (chain-A,  a) with a Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance of 4.694Å. Similarly, neighboring Cu2 atoms are conjoined via gauche-gauche conformation glu ligands to form crystallographically distinct [Cu(glu)] n  1D chains (chain-B, b) with a Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance over 0.1Å closer, at 4.589Å. The varying glu conformations instill different twists of neighboring copper square pyramidal coordination spheres (29° in chain-A, 43° in chain-B). Cu⋅⋅⋅O semi-ligation within both chain-A and chain-B provides [Cu⋅⋅⋅O-Cu⋅⋅⋅O-] n  chain patterns, with Cu⋅⋅⋅O distances of 2.778 and 2.600Å within chain-A and chain-B, respectively.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">
<ce:italic>Chain-A</ce:italic> 1D motifs connect into a 2D [Cu(glu)(dpa)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> layered motif (<ce:italic>layer-A</ce:italic>) through tethering dpa ligands, with a Cu<ce:bold>···</ce:bold>Cu through-diimine distance of 11.477<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å. In <ce:italic>layer-A</ce:italic> the inter-ring torsion angle within the dpa ligands subtends 31.1°. In turn, <ce:italic>chain-B</ce:italic> 1D patterns link into similar 2D [Cu(glu)(dpa)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> units (<ce:italic>layer-B</ce:italic>), with a shorter Cu<ce:bold>···</ce:bold>Cu through-dpa distance of 11.420<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å fostered by the inter-ring torsion angle of 32.2°. A similar trend, where less acute inter-ring torsion angles result in a shorter through-dpa metal–metal tethering distance, has been observed in other dpa-based aliphatic dicarboxylate coordination polymers . Crystallographically distinct <ce:italic>layer-A</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>layer-B</ce:italic> motifs then stack in an offset alternating pattern via hydrogen bonding mechanisms (
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl3"></ce:float-anchor>) mediated by the central amine units of the dpa ligands (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig7"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Chain-A 1D motifs connect into a 2D [Cu(glu)(dpa)] n  layered motif (layer-A) through tethering dpa ligands, with a Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu through-diimine distance of 11.477Å. In layer-A the inter-ring torsion angle within the dpa ligands subtends 31.1°. In turn, chain-B 1D patterns link into similar 2D [Cu(glu)(dpa)] n  units (layer-B), with a shorter Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu through-dpa distance of 11.420Å fostered by the inter-ring torsion angle of 32.2°. A similar trend, where less acute inter-ring torsion angles result in a shorter through-dpa metal-metal tethering distance, has been observed in other dpa-based aliphatic dicarboxylate coordination polymers . Crystallographically distinct layer-A and layer-B motifs then stack in an offset alternating pattern via hydrogen bonding mechanisms ( ) mediated by the central amine units of the dpa ligands ( ).

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">At 293<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>K, the same crystal of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> gave single-crystal X-ray diffraction data that could only be acceptably solved in the centrosymmetric orthorhombic space group <ce:italic>Pbcn</ce:italic>. The asymmetric unit consists of one divalent copper ion, one glu dianion and one ligated dpa molecule (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig8"></ce:float-anchor>). Similar to <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the copper atom displays a distorted square pyramidal [MN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>] coordination geometry (<ce:italic>τ</ce:italic>=0.26) with <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> nitrogen donors from two different dpa ligands anchoring the basal plane. The apical bond length, to a glu carboxylate oxygen atom is elongated by ∼0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å due to the Jahn–Teller active <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">9</ce:sup> electronic configuration. Bond lengths and angles (
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl4"></ce:float-anchor>) are consistent with divalent copper in a distorted square pyramidal coordination environment. The flexible glu ligands in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are disordered equally over two sets of positions; one set represents a <ce:italic>gauche</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>gauche</ce:italic> conformation with C–C–C–C torsion angles of 68.0/72.0°, while the other set marks a contrasting <ce:italic>gauche</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>anti</ce:italic> conformation (64.7/151.1° four-atom torsion angles). The terminal carbon atoms within the glu chain are common to both disordered conformations.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: At 293K, the same crystal of 3 gave single-crystal X-ray diffraction data that could only be acceptably solved in the centrosymmetric orthorhombic space group Pbcn. The asymmetric unit consists of one divalent copper ion, one glu dianion and one ligated dpa molecule ( ). Similar to 1 and 2, the copper atom displays a distorted square pyramidal [MN2O3] coordination geometry (τ=0.26) with trans nitrogen donors from two different dpa ligands anchoring the basal plane. The apical bond length, to a glu carboxylate oxygen atom is elongated by ~0.2Å due to the Jahn-Teller active d 9 electronic configuration. Bond lengths and angles ( ) are consistent with divalent copper in a distorted square pyramidal coordination environment. The flexible glu ligands in 1 are disordered equally over two sets of positions; one set represents a gauche-gauche conformation with C-C-C-C torsion angles of 68.0/72.0°, while the other set marks a contrasting gauche-anti conformation (64.7/151.1° four-atom torsion angles). The terminal carbon atoms within the glu chain are common to both disordered conformations.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Adjacent copper ions are conjoined into zigzag 1D [Cu(glu)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> chains virtually identical to those in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> by bridging glu carboxylate termini in a <ce:italic>syn</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>anti</ce:italic> binding mode, in which the basal plane of one square pyramidal coordination sphere is linked to the apical position of another. The Cu<ce:bold>···</ce:bold>Cu distance along the chain motif in the high temperature form of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> measures 4.653<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å. Covalent connectivity within the [Cu(glu)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> chains is supplemented by semi-ligation on the part of one of the oxygen donor atoms involved in the 1,5-chelating binding mode of the glu ligands. This oxygen donor atom is bound at the apical coordination site of one copper ion, and donates electron density towards the vacant coordination site of another copper ion. The semi-ligating Cu<ce:bold>···</ce:bold>O distance is 2.684<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å, causing a Cu<ce:bold>···</ce:bold>O–Cu angle of 139.4<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>°.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Adjacent copper ions are conjoined into zigzag 1D [Cu(glu)] n  chains virtually identical to those in 1 and 2 by bridging glu carboxylate termini in a syn-anti binding mode, in which the basal plane of one square pyramidal coordination sphere is linked to the apical position of another. The Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance along the chain motif in the high temperature form of 3 measures 4.653Å. Covalent connectivity within the [Cu(glu)] n  chains is supplemented by semi-ligation on the part of one of the oxygen donor atoms involved in the 1,5-chelating binding mode of the glu ligands. This oxygen donor atom is bound at the apical coordination site of one copper ion, and donates electron density towards the vacant coordination site of another copper ion. The semi-ligating Cu⋅⋅⋅O distance is 2.684Å, causing a Cu⋅⋅⋅O-Cu angle of 139.4°.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">As in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, dipodal dpa ligands link the [Cu(glu)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> chains into (4,4) rectangular grid ruffled 2D [Cu(glu)(dpa)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> layers. The Cu<ce:bold>···</ce:bold>Cu contact distance through the bridging dpa ligands is 11.472<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å, with an inter-ring torsion within the dpa ligands of 31.7°. The structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> contrasts markedly with that observed with that of its rigid-rod analog [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(glu)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4,4′-bpy)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>, which contains 2D [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(glu)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> layers strutted by 4,4′-bpy ligands into a rare 3D <ce:italic>rob</ce:italic> topology . Neighboring crystallographically identical [Cu(glu)(dpa)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> layers in the high temperature polymorph of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are organized into the <ce:italic>pseudo</ce:italic> 3D structure, stacking in an <ce:italic>ABAB</ce:italic> repeat pattern through similar hydrogen bonding patterns as seen in the Co and Ni analogues ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As in 1 and 2, dipodal dpa ligands link the [Cu(glu)] n  chains into (4,4) rectangular grid ruffled 2D [Cu(glu)(dpa)] n  layers. The Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu contact distance through the bridging dpa ligands is 11.472Å, with an inter-ring torsion within the dpa ligands of 31.7°. The structure of 3 contrasts markedly with that observed with that of its rigid-rod analog [Cu2(glu)2(4,4'-bpy)] n , which contains 2D [Cu2(glu)2] n  layers strutted by 4,4'-bpy ligands into a rare 3D rob topology . Neighboring crystallographically identical [Cu(glu)(dpa)] n  layers in the high temperature polymorph of 3 are organized into the pseudo 3D structure, stacking in an ABAB repeat pattern through similar hydrogen bonding patterns as seen in the Co and Ni analogues ().

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Thus, the low temperature and high temperature forms of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> can be considered polymorphs that can be transformed through a SCSC process. Most SCSC transformations in coordination polymers involve the absorption or desorption of guest molecules , and in some rare cases the rearrangement of covalent bonds . The thermally induced SCSC transformation in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is not as dramatic, instead more closely mirroring SCSC transformations in organic systems occurring by conformational readjustments . Nevertheless the conformational changes in the flexible glu ligand with coordination polymer <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> provide a mechanism to toggle between acentric and centrosymmetric crystal forms.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Thus, the low temperature and high temperature forms of 3 can be considered polymorphs that can be transformed through a SCSC process. Most SCSC transformations in coordination polymers involve the absorption or desorption of guest molecules , and in some rare cases the rearrangement of covalent bonds . The thermally induced SCSC transformation in 3 is not as dramatic, instead more closely mirroring SCSC transformations in organic systems occurring by conformational readjustments . Nevertheless the conformational changes in the flexible glu ligand with coordination polymer 3 provide a mechanism to toggle between acentric and centrosymmetric crystal forms.

<ce:section-title>Magnetic properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements were undertaken to investigate the level of spin communication through the [M<ce:bold>···</ce:bold>O–M<ce:bold>···</ce:bold>O–]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> chain patterns within the [M(glu)(dpa)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> coordination polymer layers. A plot of the <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">m</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> product vs <ce:italic>T</ce:italic> for the nickel derivative <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> reveals a slow descending curve between 300 and ∼30<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>K with a sharper decrease thereafter, potentially indicative of weak antiferromagnetic coupling between neighboring nickel atoms. The data were fit to the expression of Fisher (Eq. )  for a 1D Heisenberg chain of coupled spins modified by the inclusion of a temperature independent paramagnetic term (TIP), with <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>=1 and all other variables having their usual magnetochemical meanings. Best fit parameters for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> as obtained by non-linear regression were (): <ce:italic>g</ce:italic>=2.117(4), <ce:italic>J</ce:italic>=–0.28(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup>, and TIP=2.9(3)×10<ce:sup loc="post">–5</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> mol<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup> with <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>={Σ[(<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">m</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">obs</ce:inf>–(<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">m</ce:inf>

elements.clean_text:
Magnetic properties of 1-3 

Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements were undertaken to investigate the level of spin communication through the [M⋅⋅⋅O-M⋅⋅⋅O-] n  chain patterns within the [M(glu)(dpa)] n  coordination polymer layers. A plot of the χ m T product vs T for the nickel derivative 2 reveals a slow descending curve between 300 and ~30K with a sharper decrease thereafter, potentially indicative of weak antiferromagnetic coupling between neighboring nickel atoms. The data were fit to the expression of Fisher (Eq. )  for a 1D Heisenberg chain of coupled spins modified by the inclusion of a temperature independent paramagnetic term (TIP), with S=1 and all other variables having their usual magnetochemical meanings. Best fit parameters for 2 as obtained by non-linear regression were (): g=2.117(4), J=-0.28(1)cm-1, and TIP=2.9(3)×10-5 cm3 mol-1 with R={Σ[(χ m T)obs-(χ m T)calc]2}1/2=3.3×10-4, with the negative sign of the exchange parameter J corroborating the likelihood of intra-chain antiferromagnetic coupling within 2.  (1)     χ    m    T =  [   (    N   g   2     β   2   S ( S + 1 )   3 k    )    (    1 + u   1 - u    )  ]  +  TIP  ( T )    where   u =  coth ( 2 JS ( S + 1 ) / kT ) - ( kT / 2 JS ( S + 1 ) )  .

As for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the variable temperature magnetic data were fit to Eq. , but with <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>=1/2. Magnetic treatment of d 7 divalent cobalt systems is complicated by both zero-field splitting and unquenched orbital angular momentum. Therefore, the data was fit to a phenomenological expression by Rueff (Eq. ) , which takes into account both competing single ion effects (D) and magnetic superexchange (J), with C being equivalent to the Curie constant of the material:  (2)     χ    m    T = A  exp ( - D / kT ) + B  exp ( J / kT )    where   A + B = C = ( 5 N   g   2     β   2   / 4 k )  .

Thus, in contrast to the antiferromagnetic tendencies seen in 2 and 3, the predominant magnetic superexchange pathway is ferromagnetic. This divergent behavior is plausibly ascribed to the overlap of different magnetic orbital sets ("eg " only in 2 and 3, both "t 2  g " and "eg " in 1), as reported for other dual-ligand coordination polymer systems . An examination of the low temperature magnetic data for 1 ( ) indicates a sharp decrease in the χ m T value below 5.5K, indicative of either long-range weak antiferromagnetic interaction through the dpa ligands, or more likely, anisotropy-driven spin canting with misalignment of neighboring spins from an idealized ferromagnetic ground state. elements.content: <ce:section-title>Thermogravimetric analysis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">All new phases were subjected to thermogravimetric analysis to probe their thermal stabilities. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> remained stable until ∼320<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>°C, whereupon removal of the organic components occurred. The remaining material at 900<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>°C, 22.8% of the original mass, corresponds roughly to the deposition of CoO (20.8% calc’d). Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibited no mass loss until ∼275<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>°C, at which point the organic ligands are expelled. The mass remnant of 31.0% at ∼440<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>°C is consistent with the production of NiCO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (33.0% calc’d); decarboxylation between ∼440<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>°C and ∼700<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>°C resulted in likely deposition of NiO (20.3% observed remaining mass, 20.8% calc’d). Compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> began to expel its organic components at ∼250<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>°C, with a sharp mass loss noted immediately thereafter. A final mass remnant of 18.7% of the original is roughly consistent with the deposition of Cu metal (17.4% calc’d). The TGA traces for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are given in Figs. S1–S3.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric analysis

All new phases were subjected to thermogravimetric analysis to probe their thermal stabilities. Compound 1 remained stable until ~320°C, whereupon removal of the organic components occurred. The remaining material at 900°C, 22.8% of the original mass, corresponds roughly to the deposition of CoO (20.8% calc'd). Compound 2 exhibited no mass loss until ~275°C, at which point the organic ligands are expelled. The mass remnant of 31.0% at ~440°C is consistent with the production of NiCO3 (33.0% calc'd); decarboxylation between ~440°C and ~700°C resulted in likely deposition of NiO (20.3% observed remaining mass, 20.8% calc'd). Compound 3 began to expel its organic components at ~250°C, with a sharp mass loss noted immediately thereafter. A final mass remnant of 18.7% of the original is roughly consistent with the deposition of Cu metal (17.4% calc'd). The TGA traces for 1-3 are given in Figs. S1-S3.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Self-assembly of divalent transition metal cations, glutarate, and the kinked diimine dpa has generated three isostructural coordination polymers wherein neutral 1D [M(glu)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> chains featuring close M<ce:bold>···</ce:bold>M contacts fostered by semi-ligation are connected into 2D (4,4) rectangular grid layers. In the case of the copper derivative, low energy conformational changes within the glu ligand, with concomitant adjustment of hydrogen-bonding pathways imparted by the amine functional groups of the dpa moieties, provides access to a single crystal-to-single crystal transformation between centrosymmetric and acentric polymorphs.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Self-assembly of divalent transition metal cations, glutarate, and the kinked diimine dpa has generated three isostructural coordination polymers wherein neutral 1D [M(glu)]n chains featuring close M⋅⋅⋅M contacts fostered by semi-ligation are connected into 2D (4,4) rectangular grid layers. In the case of the copper derivative, low energy conformational changes within the glu ligand, with concomitant adjustment of hydrogen-bonding pathways imparted by the amine functional groups of the dpa moieties, provides access to a single crystal-to-single crystal transformation between centrosymmetric and acentric polymorphs.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The structures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> vary very significantly from their derivatives incorporating either shorter or longer α,ω-dicarboxylate ligands . Among these succinate or adipate complexes, only [Co(adipate)(dpa)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> possesses metal–metal contacts close enough for magnetic communication, within its discrete {Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} dinuclear units. Thus, the unique conformational capabilities of the glutarate ligands, in tandem with the kinked donor disposition and hydrogen-bonding facility of the dpa tethers, results in a family of coordination polymers with 1D [M<ce:bold>···</ce:bold>O–M<ce:bold>···</ce:bold>O–]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> chain motifs possessing varying magnetic interactions. The nickel and copper derivatives show weak antiferromagnetic coupling along the chain motifs; the variable temperature magnetic behavior in both cases could be interpreted successfully using a classic model. On the other hand, the cobalt analog exhibits competing ferromagnetic ordering and zero-field effects, which results in possible spin-canting behavior at low temperature. Further work towards the synthesis of coordination polymers incorporating substituted or unsubstituted α,ω-dicarboxylate ligands and tethering, hydrogen-bonding capable organodiimines is certain to afford materials with novel topologies and intriguing physicochemical properties.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The structures of 1-3 vary very significantly from their derivatives incorporating either shorter or longer α,ω-dicarboxylate ligands . Among these succinate or adipate complexes, only [Co(adipate)(dpa)] n  possesses metal-metal contacts close enough for magnetic communication, within its discrete {Co2} dinuclear units. Thus, the unique conformational capabilities of the glutarate ligands, in tandem with the kinked donor disposition and hydrogen-bonding facility of the dpa tethers, results in a family of coordination polymers with 1D [M⋅⋅⋅O-M⋅⋅⋅O-] n  chain motifs possessing varying magnetic interactions. The nickel and copper derivatives show weak antiferromagnetic coupling along the chain motifs; the variable temperature magnetic behavior in both cases could be interpreted successfully using a classic model. On the other hand, the cobalt analog exhibits competing ferromagnetic ordering and zero-field effects, which results in possible spin-canting behavior at low temperature. Further work towards the synthesis of coordination polymers incorporating substituted or unsubstituted α,ω-dicarboxylate ligands and tethering, hydrogen-bonding capable organodiimines is certain to afford materials with novel topologies and intriguing physicochemical properties.

Preparation of [Co(glu)(dpa)]n (1)

CoCl2 ⋅6H2O (88mg, 0.37mmol), dpa (127mg, 0.73mmol), and glutaric acid (49mg, 0.37mmol) were placed into 10mL distilled H2O in a 23mL Teflon-lined Parr acid digestion bomb. The bomb was sealed and heated at 120°C for 48h, whereupon it was cooled slowly to 25°C. Large single crystalline blocks of 1 (110mg, 82% yield based on Co) were isolated after washing with distilled water, ethanol, and acetone and drying in air. Crystals of 1 display pleochroism, appearing brown, orange, or violet depending on their orientation with respect to a bright light source. Anal. Calc. for C15H15CoN3O4 1: C, 50.01; H, 4.20; N, 11.67%. Found: C, 49.50; H, 3.93; N, 11.43%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3450w br (NH), 3292w, 3074w, 2971m, 2925s, 2858m (CH), 1638m, 1596s (CO2 asym), 1561s, 1535s, 1492m, 1462m, 1443m, 1404m, 1359m (CO2 sym), 1332m, 1297w, 1252w, 1211m, 1150w, 1070w, 1064w, 1021m, 910w, 857m, 819m, 735w, 677w, 650m, 620w, 589w, 532m.

Preparation of [Ni(glu)(dpa)]n (2)

The procedure for 1 above was followed, using NiCl2 ⋅6H2O (88mg, 0.37mmol), dpa (127mg, 0.73mmol) and glutaric acid (49mg, 0.37mmol). For optimized yields, the best reaction temperature was determined to be 150°C. Green blocks of 2 (72mg, 54% yield based on Ni) were isolated after washing with distilled water, ethanol, and acetone and drying in air. Calc. for C15H15NiN3O4 2: C, 50.04; H, 4.20; N, 11.67%; Found: C, 49.84; H, 3.97; N, 11.55%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3450 w br (NH), 3292 w, 3074 w, 2971m, 2921s, 2848m, 1638m, 1577s, 1557s, 1538s (CO2 asym), 1508m, 1492m, 1466m, 1443m, 1404m, 1359m (CO2 sym), 1332m, 1295 w, 1252 w, 1213m, 1152 w, 1070 w, 1064 w, 1021m, 910 w, 861m, 826m, 734 w, 679 w, 658m, 646m, 631 w, 596m, 543m.

Preparation of [Cu(glu)(dpa)]n (3)

The procedure for 1 above was followed, using CuCl2 ⋅2H2O (63mg, 0.37mmol), dpa (127mg, 0.73mmol), and glutaric acid (49mg, 0.37mmol). Blue blocks of 3 (59mg, 44% yield based on Cu) were isolated after washing with distilled water, ethanol, and acetone and drying in air. Calc. for C15H15CuN3O4 3: C, 49.38; H, 4.14; N, 11.52%. Found: C, 49.08; H, 3.99; N, 11.53%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 2903wbr, 1632w, 1580s, 1542s (CO2 asym), 1523s, 1487s, 1455m, 1440m, 1416m, 1388m, 1351s (CO2 sym), 1327m, 1299m, 1274w, 1251w, 1207s, 1160w, 1067w, 1057m, 1042w, 1024s, 907m, 857w, 840w, 819s, 799m, 730w, 679w, 663w.

The X-ray diffraction experiment for the same single crystal of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> was repeated at 293<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>K. Reflection data was acquired using graphite-monochromated Mo<ce:italic>K</ce:italic>α radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>=0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å). The data was integrated via SAINT . Lorentz and polarization effect and empirical absorption corrections were applied with SADABS . The structures were solved using direct methods and refined on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> using SHELXTL . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. X-ray crystallography

A brown block of 1 (with dimensions 0.78mm×0.56mm×0.48mm), a green block of 2 (0.42mm×0.20mm×0.18mm), and a blue block of 3 (0.24mm×0.10mm×0.10mm) were subjected to single crystal X-ray diffraction using a Bruker-AXS SMART 1k CCD instrument at 173K. The X-ray diffraction experiment for the same single crystal of 3 was repeated at 293K. Reflection data was acquired using graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ=0.71073Å). The data was integrated via SAINT . Lorentz and polarization effect and empirical absorption corrections were applied with SADABS . The structures were solved using direct methods and refined on F 2 using SHELXTL . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms bound to carbon atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined isotropically with a riding model. The hydrogen atoms bound to the central nitrogen of the dpa moieties in 1-3 were found via Fourier difference maps, then restrained at fixed positions and refined isotropically. Attempts to refine the crystal structure of 3 using the low temperature reflection data in the higher symmetry centrosymmetric space group Pbcm with a disordered glutarate conformation model resulted in unacceptably high wR2  values (~0.52), with 355 systematic absence violations. Acceptable solution was possible only in Pca21 with racemic twinning taken into account. Conversely, the crystal structure of 3 could not be acceptably solved in an acentric orthorhombic space group using the high temperature reflection data. Relevant crystallographic data for 1, 2, and 3 (at both 173 and 293K) are listed in  .

Structural description of [M(glu)(dpa)] n  (M=Co, 1; M=Ni, 2)

As revealed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, compounds 1 and 2 are isomorphous and crystallize in the centrosymmetric orthorhombic space group Pbcn with an asymmetric unit consisting of one divalent metal ion, one glu dianion and one ligated dpa molecule ( , shown for 1). The metal atoms display a distorted square pyramidal [MN2O3] coordination geometry (τ=0.223 for 1, 0.224 for 2)  with trans nitrogen donors from two different dpa ligands anchoring the basal plane. A glu dianion in a 1,5-chelating binding mode fulfills the apical coordination site and one position in the basal plane. The glu ligands in these complexes adopt gauche-gauche conformations with four C-atom torsion angles of 62.6° and 65.9° for 1 and 62.2° and 65.4° for 2. The fourth and final basal plane coordination site in each case is occupied by an oxygen atom from a second glu ligand. Bond lengths and angles () are consistent with divalent cobalt and nickel in a distorted square pyramidal coordination environment, with subtle differences consistent with well-established ionic radius trends .

Adjacent metal ions are conjoined into zigzag 1D [M(glu)] n  chains parallel to the b crystal direction ( ) through bridging glu carboxylate termini in a syn-anti binding mode, in which the basal plane of one square pyramidal coordination sphere is linked to the apical position of another. The M⋅⋅⋅M distances along the chain motifs in 1 and 2 measure 4.294 and 4.264Å, respectively. Covalent connectivity within the [M(glu)] n  chains is supplemented by semi-ligation  on the part of one of the oxygen donor atoms involved in the 1,5-chelating binding mode of the glu ligands. This oxygen donor atom is bound at the apical coordination site of one metal ion, and donates electron density towards the vacant coordination site of another metal ion. Thus, a 1D repeating [M⋅⋅⋅O-M⋅⋅⋅O-] n  chain within the larger [M(glu)] n  chain unit can be invoked. The semi-ligating M⋅⋅⋅O distances in 1 and 2 are 2.432 and 2.417Å, respectively, causing respective M⋅⋅⋅O-M angles of 144.4° and 145.2°.

Adjacent Cu1 atoms are linked through the gauch-anti conformation glu ligands to form [Cu(glu)] n  1D chains (chain-A,  a) with a Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance of 4.694Å. Similarly, neighboring Cu2 atoms are conjoined via gauche-gauche conformation glu ligands to form crystallographically distinct [Cu(glu)] n  1D chains (chain-B, b) with a Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance over 0.1Å closer, at 4.589Å. The varying glu conformations instill different twists of neighboring copper square pyramidal coordination spheres (29° in chain-A, 43° in chain-B). Cu⋅⋅⋅O semi-ligation within both chain-A and chain-B provides [Cu⋅⋅⋅O-Cu⋅⋅⋅O-] n  chain patterns, with Cu⋅⋅⋅O distances of 2.778 and 2.600Å within chain-A and chain-B, respectively.

Adjacent copper ions are conjoined into zigzag 1D [Cu(glu)] n  chains virtually identical to those in 1 and 2 by bridging glu carboxylate termini in a syn-anti binding mode, in which the basal plane of one square pyramidal coordination sphere is linked to the apical position of another. The Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance along the chain motif in the high temperature form of 3 measures 4.653Å. Covalent connectivity within the [Cu(glu)] n  chains is supplemented by semi-ligation on the part of one of the oxygen donor atoms involved in the 1,5-chelating binding mode of the glu ligands. This oxygen donor atom is bound at the apical coordination site of one copper ion, and donates electron density towards the vacant coordination site of another copper ion. The semi-ligating Cu⋅⋅⋅O distance is 2.684Å, causing a Cu⋅⋅⋅O-Cu angle of 139.4°.

<ce:section-title>Magnetic properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements were undertaken to investigate the level of spin communication through the [M<ce:bold>···</ce:bold>O–M<ce:bold>···</ce:bold>O–]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> chain patterns within the [M(glu)(dpa)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> coordination polymer layers. A plot of the <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">m</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> product vs <ce:italic>T</ce:italic> for the nickel derivative <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> reveals a slow descending curve between 300 and ∼30<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>K with a sharper decrease thereafter, potentially indicative of weak antiferromagnetic coupling between neighboring nickel atoms. The data were fit to the expression of Fisher (Eq. )  for a 1D Heisenberg chain of coupled spins modified by the inclusion of a temperature independent paramagnetic term (TIP), with <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>=1 and all other variables having their usual magnetochemical meanings. Best fit parameters for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> as obtained by non-linear regression were (): <ce:italic>g</ce:italic>=2.117(4), <ce:italic>J</ce:italic>=–0.28(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup>, and TIP=2.9(3)×10<ce:sup loc="post">–5</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> mol<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup> with <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>={Σ[(<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">m</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">obs</ce:inf>–(<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">m</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">calc</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>}<ce:sup loc="post">1/2</ce:sup>=3.3×10<ce:sup loc="post">–4</ce:sup>, with the negative sign of the exchange parameter <ce:italic>J</ce:italic> corroborating the likelihood of intra-chain antiferromagnetic coupling within <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.<ce:display>

cln_elements.clean_text:
Magnetic properties of 1-3 

Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements were undertaken to investigate the level of spin communication through the [M⋅⋅⋅O-M⋅⋅⋅O-] n  chain patterns within the [M(glu)(dpa)] n  coordination polymer layers. A plot of the χ m T product vs T for the nickel derivative 2 reveals a slow descending curve between 300 and ~30K with a sharper decrease thereafter, potentially indicative of weak antiferromagnetic coupling between neighboring nickel atoms. The data were fit to the expression of Fisher (Eq. )  for a 1D Heisenberg chain of coupled spins modified by the inclusion of a temperature independent paramagnetic term (TIP), with S=1 and all other variables having their usual magnetochemical meanings. Best fit parameters for 2 as obtained by non-linear regression were (): g=2.117(4), J=-0.28(1)cm-1, and TIP=2.9(3)×10-5 cm3 mol-1 with R={Σ[(χ m T)obs-(χ m T)calc]2}1/2=3.3×10-4, with the negative sign of the exchange parameter J corroborating the likelihood of intra-chain antiferromagnetic coupling within 2.  (1)     χ    m    T =  [   (    N   g   2     β   2   S ( S + 1 )   3 k    )    (    1 + u   1 - u    )  ]  +  TIP  ( T )    where   u =  coth ( 2 JS ( S + 1 ) / kT ) - ( kT / 2 JS ( S + 1 ) )  .

A plot of the χm T product vs T for the copper derivative 3 portrays a smooth decline between 300 and 10K with a precipitous drop at lower temperatures, hinting towards antiferromagnetic coupling between neighboring copper atoms. As for 2, the variable temperature magnetic data were fit to Eq. , but with S=1/2. Best fit parameters for 3 () were: g=2.110(5), J=-0.33(1)cm-1, and TIP=1.02(1)×10-3 cm3 mol-1 with R=1.4×10-4. Thus both 2 and 3 appear to exhibit antiferromagnetic superexchange through their respective 1D [M⋅⋅⋅O-M⋅⋅⋅O-] n  chain motifs.

A plot of the χm T product vs T for the cobalt derivative 1 shows a smooth decrease from 300-15K, below which point it increases to 4.0cm3 Kmol-1 at 5.5K, only to decrease again at low temperatures. Magnetic treatment of d 7 divalent cobalt systems is complicated by both zero-field splitting and unquenched orbital angular momentum. Therefore, the data was fit to a phenomenological expression by Rueff (Eq. ) , which takes into account both competing single ion effects (D) and magnetic superexchange (J), with C being equivalent to the Curie constant of the material:  (2)     χ    m    T = A  exp ( - D / kT ) + B  exp ( J / kT )    where   A + B = C = ( 5 N   g   2     β   2   / 4 k )  .

<ce:para view="all">Fitting the variable temperature susceptibility data to Eq.  resulted in best-fit parameters (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig9"></ce:float-anchor>) of <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>=2.36(3) (giving <ce:italic>g</ce:italic>=2.24), <ce:italic>D</ce:italic>=30(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>J</ce:italic>=14(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup> with <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>=3.0×10<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup>. Thus, in contrast to the antiferromagnetic tendencies seen in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the predominant magnetic superexchange pathway is ferromagnetic. This divergent behavior is plausibly ascribed to the overlap of different magnetic orbital sets (“<ce:italic>e<ce:inf loc="post">g</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>” only in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, both “<ce:italic>t</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">g</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>” and “<ce:italic>e<ce:inf loc="post">g</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>” in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), as reported for other dual-ligand coordination polymer systems . An examination of the low temperature magnetic data for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig10"></ce:float-anchor>) indicates a sharp decrease in the <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">m</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> value below 5.5<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>K, indicative of either long-range weak antiferromagnetic interaction through the dpa ligands, or more likely, anisotropy-driven spin canting with misalignment of neighboring spins from an idealized ferromagnetic ground state. The data below 5.5<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>K could not be acceptably fit with Eq. .</ce:para><ce:section-title>Thermogravimetric analysis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">All new phases were subjected to thermogravimetric analysis to probe their thermal stabilities. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> remained stable until ∼320<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>°C, whereupon removal of the organic components occurred. The remaining material at 900<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>°C, 22.8% of the original mass, corresponds roughly to the deposition of CoO (20.8% calc’d). Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibited no mass loss until ∼275<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>°C, at which point the organic ligands are expelled. The mass remnant of 31.0% at ∼440<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>°C is consistent with the production of NiCO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (33.0% calc’d); decarboxylation between ∼440<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>°C and ∼700<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>°C resulted in likely deposition of NiO (20.3% observed remaining mass, 20.8% calc’d). Compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> began to expel its organic components at ∼250<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>°C, with a sharp mass loss noted immediately thereafter. A final mass remnant of 18.7% of the original is roughly consistent with the deposition of Cu metal (17.4% calc’d). The TGA traces for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are given in Figs. S1–S3.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Fitting the variable temperature susceptibility data to Eq.  resulted in best-fit parameters ( ) of C=2.36(3) (giving g=2.24), D=30(1)cm-1, J=14(1)cm-1 with R=3.0×10-3. Thus, in contrast to the antiferromagnetic tendencies seen in 2 and 3, the predominant magnetic superexchange pathway is ferromagnetic. This divergent behavior is plausibly ascribed to the overlap of different magnetic orbital sets ("eg " only in 2 and 3, both "t 2  g " and "eg " in 1), as reported for other dual-ligand coordination polymer systems . An examination of the low temperature magnetic data for 1 ( ) indicates a sharp decrease in the χ m T value below 5.5K, indicative of either long-range weak antiferromagnetic interaction through the dpa ligands, or more likely, anisotropy-driven spin canting with misalignment of neighboring spins from an idealized ferromagnetic ground state. The data below 5.5K could not be acceptably fit with Eq. .

Thermogravimetric analysis

All new phases were subjected to thermogravimetric analysis to probe their thermal stabilities. Compound 1 remained stable until ~320°C, whereupon removal of the organic components occurred. The remaining material at 900°C, 22.8% of the original mass, corresponds roughly to the deposition of CoO (20.8% calc'd). Compound 2 exhibited no mass loss until ~275°C, at which point the organic ligands are expelled. The mass remnant of 31.0% at ~440°C is consistent with the production of NiCO3 (33.0% calc'd); decarboxylation between ~440°C and ~700°C resulted in likely deposition of NiO (20.3% observed remaining mass, 20.8% calc'd). Compound 3 began to expel its organic components at ~250°C, with a sharp mass loss noted immediately thereafter. A final mass remnant of 18.7% of the original is roughly consistent with the deposition of Cu metal (17.4% calc'd). The TGA traces for 1-3 are given in Figs. S1-S3.

<ce:figure id="fig1">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Coordination environment of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Thermal ellipsoids are shown at 50% probability with partial atom numbering scheme. Hydrogen atoms are represented as sticks. The coordination environment of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is very similar.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  Coordination environment of 1. Thermal ellipsoids are shown at 50% probability with partial atom numbering scheme. Hydrogen atoms are represented as sticks. The coordination environment of 2 is very similar.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig2">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">A [Co(glu)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> chain in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, with semi-ligating interactions shown as dashed lines. The semi-chelating oxygen atom is covalently bound at the apical site of the square pyramidal coordination environment.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
